clusters.title: Job Creation
clusters.description: Artificial intelligence is projected to significantly impact the job market by creating millions of new jobs and increasing demand for specialized roles. By 2025, AI could generate 97 million new jobs, resulting in a net gain of 12 million jobs. The demand for AI and machine learning specialists is expected to rise by 40% by 2027, alongside a substantial increase in roles such as data analysts, scientists, and information security analysts. Additionally, AI's economic impact is estimated to reach $15.7 trillion by 2030.

related_facts.fact_group_content: Over 120 million workers are poised to undergo retraining in the next three years.
Seventy-five million to 375 million may need to switch occupational categories and learn new skills.
Up to one-third of the 2030 workforce in the United States and Germany may need to learn new skills and find work in new occupations.
Nearly half of the 2030 workforce in Japan may need to learn new skills and find work in new occupations.
Between 400 million and 800 million individuals could be displaced by automation and need to find new jobs by 2030.
China faces up to 100 million workers needing to switch occupations if automation is adopted rapidly.
12 percent of the 2030 workforce in China may need to switch occupations.
By 2030, there will be at least 300 million more people aged 65 years and older than there were in 2014.
8 to 9 percent of 2030 labor demand will be in new types of occupations that have not existed before.

clusters.title: Workforce Shift
clusters.description: The global workforce is undergoing significant changes due to automation and demographic shifts. By 2030, millions of workers will need to retrain or switch occupations as automation displaces jobs. Countries like China, the United States, Germany, and Japan will see substantial portions of their workforce needing to adapt to new roles. Additionally, a notable percentage of future labor demand will be in occupations that do not currently exist.

China faces up to 100 million workers needing to switch occupations if automation is adopted rapidly.
12 percent of the 2030 workforce in China may need to switch occupations.

related_facts.fact_group_content: High-AI-exposure, low-automation-risk professions make up an estimated 16% of the U.S. workforce.
Occupations with both high AI exposure and high risk of automation account for an estimated 9% of all workers nationally.
The majority of occupations, about 75% of total employment, are unlikely to be significantly impacted by AI.
About half the activities people are paid to do globally could theoretically be automated.
Less than 5 percent of occupations consist of activities that can be fully automated.
In about 60 percent of occupations, at least one-third of the constituent activities could be automated.
Between almost zero and 30 percent of the hours worked globally could be automated by 2030.
The midpoint scenario is automation of 15 percent of current activities.
General automation could still impact up to half of the workforce in states like Indiana, Arkansas, and Nevada.

clusters.title: Automation Risk
clusters.description: A significant portion of the U.S. workforce, approximately 16%, is in professions with high AI exposure but low automation risk. Conversely, 9% of workers are in jobs with both high AI exposure and high automation risk. While 75% of occupations are unlikely to be significantly impacted by AI, general automation could affect up to half of the workforce in certain states. Globally, about half of the activities people are paid to do could theoretically be automated, with less than 5% of occupations being fully automatable.

9% of workers in high-AI, high-risk jobs
75% of jobs unlikely to be impacted by AI

merged_facts.merged_content: AI and automation impact on U.S. workforce. High-AI-exposure, low-automation-risk professions make up 16% of the U.S. workforce. Occupations with both high AI exposure and high risk of automation account for 9% of all workers nationally, especially in states like South Dakota, Kansas, Delaware, Florida, and New York. The majority of occupations, about 75% of total employment, in the U.S. are unlikely to be significantly impacted by AI.

Occupations with both high AI exposure and high risk of automation account for an estimated 9% of all workers nationally.
The majority of occupations, about 75% of total employment, are unlikely to be significantly impacted by AI.
General automation could still impact up to half of the workforce in states like Indiana, Arkansas, and Nevada.
About half the activities people are paid to do globally could theoretically be automated.
Less than 5 percent of occupations consist of activities that can be fully automated.
In about 60 percent of occupations, at least one-third of the constituent activities could be automated.
Between almost zero and 30 percent of the hours worked globally could be automated by 2030.
The midpoint scenario is automation of 15 percent of current activities.

clusters.title: Market Impact
clusters.description: AI is projected to significantly impact the job market, with estimates suggesting it could displace millions of jobs globally by 2030. In the United States alone, AI might overtake 45 million jobs by 2030, and it has already contributed to job losses in 2023. The technology's influence extends to affecting a substantial portion of working hours and hindering job recovery post-pandemic.
